Award.AwardTitle: Japan-US Seminar on Two-Phase Flow Dynamics; Hokkaido, Japan

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1705474
PI: Tryggvason, Gretar

This award will support participation of US scientists and engineers at the Japan-US Seminar on Two-Phase Flow Dynamics, which will be held June 22-24, 2017 at Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan. This is the 11th seminar in a series that started in 1979. The goal of the seminar is to enhance progress in understanding two-phase flow dynamics and to accelerate the development of improved measurement techniques and predictive computational models. Multiphase flows are found in many industrial processes, including boiling heat transfer in conventional boilers and nuclear reactors, atomization of liquid fuels, flow through porous media, filtration and separations, and certain kinds of catalytic reactors. Multiphase flows are found in naturally-occurring processes, including heat and mass transfer at air-ocean interfaces, cloud formation and precipitation, sandstorms, avalanches, and coastal sediment transport.

The goals of the symposium are to disseminate recent research findings, establish new collaborations, and improve the training of students in multiphase flow phenomena. The meeting will consist of a series of keynote lectures and research presentations. Sessions topics will focus on evaporating flows, microscale two-phase flows, bubble swarms, numerical challenges, gas-liquid interfacial dynamics, bubbly shear flows, advances in measurement techniques, flow visualization, high-speed interfacial flows. The seminar will also include laboratory tours and reports on two-phase flow research activities in the US, Japan and EU. Support will be provided to emerging scientists and junior faculty members with the goal of engaging young researchers in the science of multiphase flows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The eleventh Japan-U.S. Seminar on Two-Phase Flow Dynamics was held at Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan, on June 22-24, 2017. The Seminar was first held in 1979 and has served as an important forum for communication advances in research on multiphase flows, particularly those aspects found in conventional and nuclear power plants. Participation is by invitation only and attendees usually include a mixture of junior and senior researchers, including some of the most accomplished people in the field. Advances in experimental techniques and diagnostics, progress in computational methods and simulations, and new ideas in modeling multiphase flows have all been discussed at the Seminars. The eleventh seminar was co-chaired by senior researchers from Japan and the United States, but organized by researchers at Hokkaido University. It consisted of nine sessions with a total of thirty-five presentations, including four keynote talks. Twelve talks, including two keynotes were presented by researchers from the United States. In addition, a special session on large scale research projects in multiphase flows consisted of short presentations and discussions by senior researchers from both countries. The delegates also visited research laboratories at Hokkaido University. The keynote presentations gave an overview of recent progress in experimental studies of shock propagation in cavitating flows, experiments on the effect of bubble clusters on turbulent flows, modeling and simulations of flow in bubble columns, and measurement of flow around large bubbles in pipes. Other presentations covered research on various aspects of gas-liquid multiphase flows, both isothermal and those undergoing phase change such as in boiling and evaporation. After the Seminar, the organizers invited several presenters to contribute full papers describing their work in more detail and after going through the regular review process, eight papers appeared in a virtual special issue of the journal Nuclear Engineering and Design. The Japan-U.S. Seminar on Two-Phase Flow Dynamics has served as an important forum for exchange of ideas and results for researchers in multiphase flows for nearly four decades and the present Seminar highlighted recent progress in advanced numerical simulation techniques and results, experiments and measurement techniques and flow visualization, and progress on modeling flows at large scale. The Seminar also provided opportunities for junior researchers to network with each other and senior colleagues from both countries.

Intellectual Merit: Multiphase flows are ubiquitous in nature and technology and predictive capabilities can have profound impact on safety and economics in a wide range of areas. Multiphase flows are, in particular, common in energy production. This included boiling heat transfer in conventional boilers and nuclear reactors, atomization of liquid fuel, cavitation in many processes, processing of biomass, and fuel cells, for example. Natural processes include rain, heat and mass transfer at the air-ocean interface, volcanic explosions, sandstorms and erosion. Significant progress is currently taking place in the development of the next generation predictive tools, based on major advances in numerical simulation, advanced measurement methods, and improved understanding of the modeling of evolving heterogeneous materials, particularly for the dynamics of interfacial structures and interfacial transfers. Both nations are advancing the state of the art in these fields and the Japan-US Seminars serve as an important communication forum to disseminate and discuss this progress.

Broader Impacts: The Seminars serves to reinforce collaborations between the two nations by maintaining established contacts between senior researchers and helping junior researchers get to know their foreign colleagues, exchange ideas, and discuss collaborations. By focusing on a specific area, the seminar does, in particularly, encourage constructive interactions from researchers focusing on computations, experiments and modeling. Predictive methods developed for multiphase flows, as well as the experimental and computational tools, have a broad applicability to a diverse set of fields, such as various aspects of biological flows and material processing, and thus the Seminars contributes to the development of a scientific workforce that is able to collaborate internationally and to tackle diverse and difficult problems.
